x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.potential_impact: The HeatShield platform aims to significantly reduce heat-related illness and deaths by delivering timely alerts and coordinating the deployment of essential cooling resources. Leveraging real-time heat hotspot data, it enables cities to engage in climate-smart urban planning, identifying where interventions like tree planting, cooling centers, or reflective infrastructure are most needed. The platform is designed to empower vulnerable communities such as the elderly, low-income families, and outdoor workers by providing early warnings and access to life-saving resources during extreme heat events. Additionally, HeatShield generates grant-reportable metrics, including risk reduction per dollar spent, giving funders and city officials clear, actionable insights into impact and return on investment. Ultimately, HeatShield establishes a scalable and replicable model for smart climate adaptation that can be deployed in cities around the world.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Cities across the developed world are experiencing extreme heatwaves due to climate change and the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect. Vulnerable populations- the elderly, low-income households, and outdoor workers face increasing health risks. Yet many cities lack real-time, localized systems to monitor urban heat risk at the neighborhood level, coordinate emergency responses and cooling resources, track response effectiveness and equity and inform long-term urban planning (e.g., where to plant trees, install reflective roofing, etc.)
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.project_name: HeatShield - Resilient Urban Heat Risk Management Platform
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

A ServiceNow app for city governments or climate NGOs that does the following:

1. Urban Heat Monitoring Dashboard

  • Ingest real-time temperature data from weather stations, satellites (e.g., Copernicus), IoT sensors
  • Map high-risk zones at the street or block level
  • Trigger alerts when thresholds are crossed (e.g., 35°C+ for >2 hrs)

2. Heat Incident & Response Coordination

  • Create heat_incident records when high-risk zones are detected
  • Auto-assign response tasks to:
  • Open cooling centers
  • Distribute water or AC units
  • Check on registered vulnerable residents (elderly, disabled)
  • Escalate unresolved cases based on time and temperature severity

3. Vulnerable Resident Registry

  • Securely store data on residents enrolled in the heat safety program
  • Track wellness check-ins and health resource distribution
  • Use consent-based data collection, integrated with health/social services

4. Cooling Resource Asset Tracker

  • Track inventory and deployment of water, shade structures, fans, reflective paint, trees, etc.
  • Manage vendor contracts and delivery timelines

5. Resilience Analytics & Planning

Post-season reports showing:

  • Heat maps before/after interventions
  • Community impact and coverage
  • Gaps in service by zip code or demographic
  • Export for city council briefings, grant reports, or academic collaboration

ServiceNow capabilities  that would be used?

  • App Engine Studio: Scoped app build
  • Flow Designer: Automated workflows for alerts, resource assignment
  • IntegrationHub: Ingest open data from NOAA, NASA, municipal IoT sensors
  • Service Portal: Resident portal for safety check-ins, cooling center lookup
  • Performance Analytics: Track response time, incident volume, population coverage
  • CMDB / Asset Management: Manage physical assets like AC units, tents, shade trees
  • Mobile App (optional): For field responders to log deliveries, check-ins

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Weather & satellite APIs: NOAA Heat Index, Copernicus Urban Atlas, Weather.gov

IoT sensors (optional): Heat sensors on lampposts or buildings

GIS integration: Optional for map overlays (Mapbox, ArcGIS)

Resident data: Opt-in health or census data for vulnerable population mapping

Open311 or city data APIs for location services

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  1. Data privacy: Resident registry must follow HIPAA/GDPR where applicable

  2. Sensor integration: Not all cities have urban heat sensors; they may require partnerships

  3. Community trust: Must engage local communities to ensure participation

  4. Funding for cooling resources: Procurement depends on external budgets

  5. Cross-departmental coordination: Need buy-in from health, emergency, public works, and IT teams
